DOCNAME: CASE OF MÜRSEL EREN v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-2;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He graduated from secondary school ( lycée ) in DATE and started sitting his university entrance examinations in DATE .

CARDINAL . At the relevant time , in order to attend a university degree course in GPE , would - be students were required to pass a CARDINAL - tier , multiple - choice examination organised by ORG Centre for ORG ( GPE PERSON ve PERSON – “ the FAC ” ) , which was held only once a year . Students who were unsuccessful in the first stage of the examination had the right to re - sit it in subsequent DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant failed to pass the first stage of the university entrance examination in his first CARDINAL attempts DATE . He was not therefore allowed to proceed to the second and final examination during that time .

CARDINAL . The applicant attended a private course in GPE in order to prepare for the DATE examinations . He submitted that during this course he studied very hard and , on occasion , obtained the highest marks in his class in mock examinations .

CARDINAL . NORP In the first stage of the examinations in DATE , the applicant obtained CARDINAL points which enabled him to proceed to the second stage , the required minimum being CARDINAL points . After the second examination the applicant believed that he had been successful and that he would obtain sufficient points to qualify for access to CARDINAL of the university programmes he had selected in his application form . When the exam results were announced , the applicant found that his name was not on the list of successful students who were allowed to enrol at a university . When he contacted the FAC he was informed that he had obtained CARDINAL points in his second examination .
CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE , the applicant asked the LAW why he had not been selected for a university place of his choice , given his good results .

CARDINAL . The LAW , in its reply of DATE , informed the applicant that he had obtained CARDINAL of the highest results among the students who had sat the second examination , but that his exam results had been annulled on the advice of an academic council , consisting of CARDINAL professors , which had found that , given his poor results in DATE , his excellent achievement could not be explained . The letter of the LAW contained no indication that it suspected the applicant of any impropriety .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , through the assistance of a lawyer , applied to ORG ( NORP ) and requested that “ the decision of the ÖSYM , which had no precedent ” , be suspended and annulled , otherwise “ his right to university education would be breached ” . He argued that the fact that his previous exam results were not good did not mean that he would never succeed in passing subsequent examinations .

CARDINAL . According to the judge rapporteur of ORG appointed in the case , the decision of the ÖSYM was based on pure supposition and should be annulled as it was devoid of any legal basis . However , on DATE , ORG , by a majority of CARDINAL , rejected the application to annul the decision of the ÖSYM , finding that it was inexplicable for a student who had obtained very poor results in his previous exams to be so successful in subsequent examinations . The minority argued in their dissenting opinion that the authorities had a duty to organise the examinations properly and that it was their responsibility to prove , with adequate evidence , any impropriety such as cheating .
CARDINAL . The applicant 's appeal , lodged on DATE , was dismissed by a majority of CARDINAL on DATE by ORG ( NORP PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant asked , in a further application submitted to ORG , for the decision of the ÖSYM to be annulled . On DATE the request was rejected by the same court after it had examined the case on its merits , by a majority of CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed and sought an injunction suspending the decision of the ORG while the appeal was being examined .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG began examining the applicant 's request for an injunction but decided to postpone the matter until after the conclusion of the appeal .

CARDINAL . NORP The appeal against the decision of CARDINAL DATE was dismissed on DATE by ORG , by a majority of CARDINAL to CARDINAL . The majority concluded that the applicant had not achieved the result through his own knowledge and ability . The minority argued in their dissenting opinion that the FAC had a duty to take measures in order to ensure that university entrance examinations and the subsequent steps leading to selection for a university place were conducted properly . The FAC had the obligation and power to punish candidates who breached the laws and regulations , if so established on the basis of adequate evidence . According to the minority , the FAC could not hold the applicant responsible for the consequences of its own failures . It could only review its procedures and take measures to prevent the repetition of such situations .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked for a rectification of the decision of CARDINAL DATE , which is the final remedy in NORP law in administrative matters .
CARDINAL . On DATE the application for the rectification of the decision was rejected by ORG . This decision was taken by a majority of CARDINAL to CARDINAL and was served on the applicant on DATE .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW provides that no one shall be denied the right to education or to instruction .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) , the ÖSYM – the Higher Education Council 's Centre for ORG is an organisation which , in the context of principles established by ORG , and in order to select students for admission to institutions of higher education , prepares tests , administers them , evaluates the results and , having regard to the preferences expressed by the successful candidate , effects their placement at universities and other higher educational institutions .
CARDINAL . The relevant part of LAW no . CARDINAL provides as follows :

“ Students are placed at higher education institutions by passing an examination , the principles of which are determined by ORG . The evaluation of the exam results takes into account the student 's secondary school grade average ... ”
